name: Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo
description_short: Peace treaty that ended the Mexican American War.
description_long: Peace treaty that ended the Mexican American War (1846–1848). One of the stipulations made it so all Mexican nationals living on newly-annexed U.S. property (Northern Mexico) had a choice between U.S. and Mexico citizenship.

name: Chinese Exclusion Act
description_short: This Act banned all Chinese laborers from immigration into the U.S. and established absolute Congressional power in controlling immigration.
description_long:
This act banned all Chinese laborers from immigrating to United States. This was the first such act targeting an ethnic group of people.

Courts "progressively narrowed the grounds for judicial review in Chinese exclusion cases over the years", (page 78, Impossible Subjects).

The Chinese Exclusion Act also established absolute Congressional rule over immigration, establishing it as a matter of "national sovereignty". Immigrants would be allowed to stay only with "the license, permission, and sufferance of Congress" (page 18, Impossible Subjects).

name: Fong Yue Ting v. United States
description_short: Ruled that deportation is not a punishment of a crime, opening doors for mistreatment of immigrants and dissidents.
description_long: The Supreme Court ruled that deportation is not a punishment of a crime. “The right of a nation to- expel or deport foreigners… is as absolute and unqualified as the right to prohibit and prevent their entrance into the country.” …“‘Deportation’ is the removal of an alien out of the country, simply because his presence is deemed inconsistent with the public welfare, and without any punishment being imposed or contemplated”, and …“The right to exclude or expel all aliens, or any class of aliens, absolutely or upon certain conditions, in war or in peace, being an inherent and inalienable right of every sovereign and independent nation, essential to its safety, its independence and its welfare”. The noncriminal nature of this opened the flood gates for mistreatment of immigrants, argues William Preston in “Aliens and Dissenters”. The Bill of Rights applied only to people charged with a crime, and so those trapped in the murky space of having committed no wrong but just deemed unworthy to stay in United States were subjected to all kinds of mistreatments, like trial without a jury, and long detention.

name: Immigration Act of 1917
description_short: This act enforced a literary test on migrants. It also barred immigration from the Asia-Pacific zone.
description_long:
Also known as the Literacy Act and the Asiatic Barred Zone act, this act excluded native inhabitants' migration into the United States from Afghanistan to the Pacific.

This Act imposed literacy tests on migrants, which was specifically aimed to curb immigration from undesirable areas of Europe (Eastern and Southern countries), and was a direct response to rising political dissent in Italy (anarchism) and Russia (Bolshevism) (Impossible Subjects, page 19).

name: The Palmer Raids
description_short: Mass deportation under the guise of national safety -- over 10,000 suspected communists and anarchists arrested
description_long:
Named for Attorney General A. Mitchell Palmer, (who hoped to get the Democratic presidential nomination and whose house was bombed by an anarchist in response to his [racist/political/hardline views]) Palmer created the Radical Division of the Justice Department and appointed J. Edgar Hoover to its head.

"Fully 90 percent of communist and anarchist agitation is traceable to aliens," said the Attorney General and presidential hopeful A. Mitchell Palmer in 1920, by way of justifying the raids that rounded up and deported 10,000 suspected radicals whom he described as "aliens… of misshapen caste of mind and indecencies of character." http://people.ischool.berkeley.edu/~nunberg/aliens.html

First big raid: 1,182 people tied to the anarchist organization Union of Russian Workers. January 2, 1920: night sweeps in more than thirty towns and cities, arresting about ten thousand people, many of them with just a tenuous tie to Communism or Socialism (including dancers at a Russian club, bakers, singers, etc).

Over 10,000 suspected communists and anarchists arrested

name: Emergency Quota Act
description_short: Instituted a restrictive quota on the amount of immigrants admitted into the U.S.
description_long:
• created in response to jews fleeing persecution in europe
  • "3% of the number of residents from that same country living in the United States "
  • law set quota according to the 1910 census (not 1920)
  • largest number admitted from northern and western europe
  • smaller number from southern and eastern nativists argued for a 2% quota instead, resulting in eastern and southern europe = 15% of the total number of immigrants

name: United States ex rel. Klonis v. Davis
description_long: "At any rate we think it not improper to-say that deportation under the circumstances would be deplorable. Whether the relator came here in arms or at the age of ten, he is as much our' product as though his mother-had borne him on American soil. He knows no other language, no other people,- no other habits, than ours; - he will be as much a-stranger in Poland as any one born of ancestors who immigrated in the seventeenth century. However heinous his crimes, deportation is to him exile, a dreadful punishment, abandoned by the common consent of all civilized peoples." - Justice Learned Hand
